thread.title: Police make more arrests in fatal 2013 shooting outside community centre
thread.title_full: Police make more arrests in fatal 2013 shooting outside community centre | CP24.com

author: Chris Fox, CP24.com
title: Police make more arrests in fatal 2013 shooting outside community centre
text:
Police have arrested another two people in connection with the fatal shooting of a 25-year-old man outside a community basketball tournament in Etobicoke almost two years ago.
Neeko Mitchell was shot numerous times as he stood outside the North Kipling Community Centre near Kipling and Finch avenues on Nov. 24, 2013.
Police have previously said that the shooting took place minutes after Mitchell arrived at the community centre to watch his brother play in a community basketball tournament known as “Jam Rock 9.”
Surveillance camera footage that was entered into evidence during a trial for a woman who was eventually convicted of accessory after the fact to murder for helping the alleged shooter escape showed Mitchell entering the community center shortly after 8 p.m. and then shaking the hand of the alleged gunman minutes before being shot.
The alleged gunman, 25-year-old Reshane Hayles-Wilson, was arrested last September and charged with first-degree murder.
He has additionally been charged with participating in the activities of a criminal organization.
Two additional suspects were arrested in connection with the shooting on Thursday.
Jermaine Dunkley, 30, of Mississauga, is charged with first-degree murder, participating in the activities of a criminal organization and instructing the commission of an offence for a criminal organization.
Sheldon Tingle, 34, of Brampton, is charged with first-degree murder and participating in the activities of a criminal organization.
According to evidence presented at the trial of the woman convicted of accessory after the fact to murder, the Crown alleges it was Dunkley who called the shots on the night of Mitchell’s shooting, though he reportedly did not fire the fatal shots.
None of the charges laid against the three male suspects have been proven in court.
